question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Factor the expression $2x(x-3) + 3(x-3)$.
inference:
$$2x(x-3) + 3(x-3)$$
$$=(x-3)(2x+3)$$
$$=\boxed{(x-3)(2x+3)}$$
Final Answer: $\boxed{(x-3)(2x+3)}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: We can factor the expression $x-3$ out of each term: \[2x(x-3) + 3(x-3) = 2x\cdot (x-3) + 3\cdot (x-3) = \boxed{(2x+3)(x-3)}.\] If you don't quite see how this works, suppose we put $A$ in place of $x-3$ everywhere in the original expression. Then we can see the factoring more clearly: \[2xA +3A = 2x\cdot A + 3\cdot A = (2x+3)A.\] Putting $x-3$ back in for $A$, we have our factorization: $(2x+3)(x-3)$.
